label.intro:
The video here below gives a brief example when measuring or ignoring in the field.

The script to the video is given here:

One example where we choose between measuring and ignoring variables is with an experiment where the outcome is the yield of millet. In this experiment, we want to know the weight of millet to know the yield.

Basically the question was with millet should you be measuring the weight of the whole stem or just the grains?

You're interested in the grains - that's what you eat, and what you actually want to know, but measuring the grains and just the grains, is difficult: When in the field and harvesting, the grains are on the stems. It is later outside of the field that it is processed, and the grains are taken off

So how reliable is the weight of the stem with the grains on it to be able to estimate the weight of the grain? To answer this, we used other research to establish the weight of the stems is reliable for the weight of the grains to be able to use the weight of the stems to estimate the weight of the grains. 

We found it was really reliable, and not only that, but it avoided all these other problems, and it was cheaper. It enabled people to scale out the whole process: measuring stems in the field is really easy and worked really well. On the back of that, chose in future years to only measure the stems. So we had multiple wins.

At the heart of this, it wouldn't have worked if not for the reliability between the stem weight and the grain weight. 

That relationship was checked, and it was found that that relationship is reliable enough to use the stem weight to estimate the grain weight.

This "stem weight" is then considered a proxy variable, we use the stem weight to calculate the grain weight.
